docs.abstract: More doctors are growing concerned about the effects of childhood poverty in an age when income inequality is increasing and social mobility is declining.
docs.snippet: More doctors are growing concerned about the effects of childhood poverty in an age when income inequality is increasing and social mobility is declining.

docs.abstract: Social isolation can adversely affect health, undermining the ability to self-regulate, raising stress and increasing inflammation, studies show.
docs.snippet: Social isolation can adversely affect health, undermining the ability to self-regulate, raising stress and increasing inflammation, studies show.

headline.seo: Seeking Clues to a Heart Killer in the DNA Binding a Family
headline.print_headline: Seeking Clues to Heart Disease in DNA of an Unlucky Family
headline.main: Seeking Clues to Heart Disease in DNA of an Unlucky Family

docs.abstract: Massive government study led by Dr Leslie Biesecker is examining the genetic makeup of seemingly healthy people who suffer from heart disease, searching for telltale mutations or aberrations in their DNA that could be root of their affliction; Rick Del Sontro, whose entire family suffers from heart disease, is one participant in study (Series: Genetic Connections).
docs.lead_paragraph: Scientists are studying the DNA of the Del Sontro family for mutations or aberrations, hoping to see if genetics can explain why heart disease strikes apparently healthy people.
docs.snippet: Scientists are studying the DNA of the Del Sontro family for mutations or aberrations, hoping to see if genetics can explain why heart disease strikes apparently healthy people.

headline.print_headline: Pay People to Cook at Home
headline.main: Pay People to Cook at Home

docs.abstract: Op-Ed article by journalist Kristin Wartman recalls long-forgotten proposal under which government would pay parents to stay at home as caretakers for children, with particular focus on providing healthy, home-cooked food; notes that plan was original conceived under aegis of feminism, but that it would also be powerful tool for fighting obesity and decline in civility and morals.
docs.lead_paragraph: Give families the time and money they need for better eating.
docs.snippet: Give families the time and money they need for better eating.

byline.original: By KATE ZERNIKE and MARC SANTORA; Randy Leonard contributed reporting

docs.abstract: New Jersey Gov Chris Christie reveals that he had weight loss surgery, lap-band procedure, in February, due to his concerns about his family and his health, not politics; Christie has shed 40 pounds. Photos (M)
docs.lead_paragraph:
Gov. Chris Christie of New Jersey ascended to become one of the country’s top political stars almost in spite of his weight — dismissing those who questioned whether his size disqualified him for higher office as “ridiculous” and “irresponsible.” 
 
Now, like some overweight politicians before him, Mr. Christie has embarked on a major effort to shed pounds at a time when his eyes are on the presidency. Saying that “a whole bunch of other things” had not worked, he revealed on Tuesday that he had undergone weight loss surgery three months ago. He is now 40 pounds lighter.
docs.snippet: Gov.  Chris Christie  of New Jersey ascended to become one of the country’s top political stars almost in spite of his weight — dismissing those who questioned whether his size disqualified him for higher office as...

headline.seo: Patients Say Gastric-Band Procedure Won’t Guarantee Weight Loss
headline.print_headline: No Easy Path To Slimness, Patients Say Of Procedure
headline.main: No Easy Path to Slimness, Patients Say of Procedure

docs.abstract: Estimated 200,000 people a year have weight-loss surgery in the United States, and banding procedure chosen by New Jersey Gov Chris Christie, placing silicone band around the upper part of stomach to restrict intake, is the least invasive and least risky type; still, those who have undergone the surgery say it is no easy path to slimness.
docs.lead_paragraph: For Gov. Chris Christie, the consequences of not sticking to a post-surgery diet could be dire, including having to run to the bathroom after eating the wrong food.
docs.snippet: For Gov. Chris Christie, the consequences of not sticking to a post-surgery diet could be dire, including having to run to the bathroom after eating the wrong food.

byline.original: By KATE ZERNIKE and MARC SANTORA

docs.abstract: New Jersey Gov Chris Christie reveals that he had weight loss surgery, lap-band procedure, in February, due to his concerns about his family and his health, not politics; Christie has shed 40 pounds.
docs.lead_paragraph: Gov. Chris Christie of New Jersey said he had a band placed around his stomach in February.
docs.snippet: Gov. Chris Christie of New Jersey said he had a band placed around his stomach in February.
